metadata.paragraph_text_preview: In the aftermath of George Floyd's death in May 2020, nationwide protests erupted, including a signi...

target:
In the aftermath of George Floyd's death in May 2020, nationwide protests erupted, including a significant demonstration in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on May 31, 2020. During the protest, the Fort Lauderdale Police Department (FLPD) attempted to disperse the crowd through use of tear gas and kinetic impact projectiles, otherwise known as rubber bullets.

The plaintiff in this case, a participant in the May 2020 demonstration, alleged she was shot in the eye by a direct impound round, causing severe, painful, and permanent physical and emotional injuries. In response to her injuries, she filed a lawsuit against the City of Fort Lauderdale and several FLPD officers in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida on May 31, 2022. The eight-count complaint alleged violations of her constitutional rights under the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments, as well as state law claims for battery and negligence. The plaintiff asserted municipal liability under a Monell “failure to train” theory. The plaintiff sought damages, including punitive damages, prejudgment interest on liquidated damages, costs, and compensatory damages. The matter was assigned to District Judge Rodolfo Armando Ruiz II.

The plaintiff filed an amended complaint on October 27, 2022, wherein she revised the list of named FLDP defendants and added two additional counts: a claim against the City of Fort Lauderdale for negligent instruction, training, and supervision of its officers and a Fourteenth Amendment Procedural Due Process claim against all defendants, alleging that FLDP officers did not issue a proper dispersal order prior to deploying force. For these additional claims, the plaintiff sought compensatory damages, costs, and injunctive relief.

On November 2 and November 10, 2022, the defendants filed a pair of motions to dismiss. Judge Ruiz issued an order on June 1, 2023, granting in part the various motions. 2023 WL 3750581. Specifically, he dismissed without prejudice with leave to amend the plaintiff’s Fourteenth Amendment claims, her Fourth Amendment claims, and, with respect to the city only, her First Amendment claim. Judge Ruiz also ordered the defendant to file a Second Amended Complaint in compliance with his order on or before June 23, 2023.

After receiving an extension of time, the plaintiff filed a Second Amended Complaint on July 6, 2023. Among other things, the amended complaint pursued a bifurcated approach wherein the plaintiff alleged separate causes of action against the city and the other defendants, where applicable, and separated First Amendment claims into two claims–one for unlawful restriction on speech and the other for retaliation. The complaint also provided a name for one of the three John Doe officers and included as an additional defendant the city’s police chief.

The plaintiff filed a Third Amended Complaint on September 13, 2023, in which she made relatively modest changes to certain of her claims and removed references to one of the named FLPD defendants added in the Second Amended Complaint, substituting back John Doe 1.

The defendants sought summary judgment in a pair of filings made on December 5, 2023, and January 12, 2024. The plaintiff also filed a motion for partial summary judgment on January 12, 2024.

On September 4, 2024, Judge Ruiz issued an order granting in part and denying in part the various summary judgment motions. 2024 WL 4039849. Specifically, he granted summary judgment in favor of the individual defendants on all counts, citing both qualified and statutory immunity. With respect to the city, he denied summary judgment on the two First Amendment claims under the plaintiff’s failure-to-train Monell theory and denied summary judgment as to the state-law battery claim, holding that it would be up to a jury to determine whether the city was liable for the plaintiff’s injuries “through its policies, procedures, and officers’ conduct.”

On October 28, 2024, before the case proceeded to trial, the parties attended mediation and came to a full and final settlement of all claims, pending final consideration and approval by the Fort Lauderdale City Commission. The city commission approved [https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/broward/article296526834.html] a $1.975 million settlement at its meeting on December 3, 2024. As part of the settlement, FLPD also agreed to overhaul its internal policies. The court approved the settlement on December 23, 2024.
target_paragraph: In the aftermath of George Floyd's death in May 2020, nationwide protests erupted, including a significant demonstration in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on May 31, 2020. During the protest, the Fort Lauderdale Police Department (FLPD) attempted to disperse the crowd through use of tear gas and kinetic impact projectiles, otherwise known as rubber bullets.

annotation.explanation: A significant protest occurred in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on May 31, 2020, following George Floyd’s death.
FLPD attempted to disperse the crowd using tear gas and rubber bullets (kinetic impact projectiles).

target:
In the aftermath of George Floyd's death in May 2020, nationwide protests erupted, including a significant demonstration in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on May 31, 2020. During the protest, the Fort Lauderdale Police Department (FLPD) attempted to disperse the crowd through use of tear gas and kinetic impact projectiles, otherwise known as rubber bullets.

The plaintiff in this case, a participant in the May 2020 demonstration, alleged she was shot in the eye by a direct impound round, causing severe, painful, and permanent physical and emotional injuries. In response to her injuries, she filed a lawsuit against the City of Fort Lauderdale and several FLPD officers in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida on May 31, 2022. The eight-count complaint alleged violations of her constitutional rights under the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments, as well as state law claims for battery and negligence. The plaintiff asserted municipal liability under a Monell “failure to train” theory. The plaintiff sought damages, including punitive damages, prejudgment interest on liquidated damages, costs, and compensatory damages. The matter was assigned to District Judge Rodolfo Armando Ruiz II.

The plaintiff filed an amended complaint on October 27, 2022, wherein she revised the list of named FLDP defendants and added two additional counts: a claim against the City of Fort Lauderdale for negligent instruction, training, and supervision of its officers and a Fourteenth Amendment Procedural Due Process claim against all defendants, alleging that FLDP officers did not issue a proper dispersal order prior to deploying force. For these additional claims, the plaintiff sought compensatory damages, costs, and injunctive relief.

On November 2 and November 10, 2022, the defendants filed a pair of motions to dismiss. Judge Ruiz issued an order on June 1, 2023, granting in part the various motions. 2023 WL 3750581. Specifically, he dismissed without prejudice with leave to amend the plaintiff’s Fourteenth Amendment claims, her Fourth Amendment claims, and, with respect to the city only, her First Amendment claim. Judge Ruiz also ordered the defendant to file a Second Amended Complaint in compliance with his order on or before June 23, 2023.

After receiving an extension of time, the plaintiff filed a Second Amended Complaint on July 6, 2023. Among other things, the amended complaint pursued a bifurcated approach wherein the plaintiff alleged separate causes of action against the city and the other defendants, where applicable, and separated First Amendment claims into two claims–one for unlawful restriction on speech and the other for retaliation. The complaint also provided a name for one of the three John Doe officers and included as an additional defendant the city’s police chief.

The plaintiff filed a Third Amended Complaint on September 13, 2023, in which she made relatively modest changes to certain of her claims and removed references to one of the named FLPD defendants added in the Second Amended Complaint, substituting back John Doe 1.

The defendants sought summary judgment in a pair of filings made on December 5, 2023, and January 12, 2024. The plaintiff also filed a motion for partial summary judgment on January 12, 2024.

On September 4, 2024, Judge Ruiz issued an order granting in part and denying in part the various summary judgment motions. 2024 WL 4039849. Specifically, he granted summary judgment in favor of the individual defendants on all counts, citing both qualified and statutory immunity. With respect to the city, he denied summary judgment on the two First Amendment claims under the plaintiff’s failure-to-train Monell theory and denied summary judgment as to the state-law battery claim, holding that it would be up to a jury to determine whether the city was liable for the plaintiff’s injuries “through its policies, procedures, and officers’ conduct.”

On October 28, 2024, before the case proceeded to trial, the parties attended mediation and came to a full and final settlement of all claims, pending final consideration and approval by the Fort Lauderdale City Commission. The city commission approved [https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/broward/article296526834.html] a $1.975 million settlement at its meeting on December 3, 2024. As part of the settlement, FLPD also agreed to overhaul its internal policies. The court approved the settlement on December 23, 2024.

annotation.explanation: Plaintiffs: Individual, described as a participant in the May 2020 demonstration who alleged she was shot in the eye by a direct impound round
Plaintiff: A participant in the May 2020 Fort Lauderdale demonstration who alleges she was shot in the eye by a kinetic impact projectile (rubber bullet), resulting in severe and permanent injuries.
Defendant: City of Fort Lauderdale (municipal entity).
Defendant: Several Fort Lauderdale Police Department (FLPD) officers (individual defendants, some initially unnamed).
The plaintiff, a protest participant, alleges she was shot in the eye by a direct projectile round, resulting in severe, painful, and permanent physical and emotional injuries.

On May 31, 2022, the plaintiff sued the City of Fort Lauderdale and several FLPD officers in S.D. Fla., alleging First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendment violations and state-law battery and negligence, asserting Monell failure-to-train municipal liability, and seeking punitive, compensatory, prejudgment interest, and costs.
Initial complaint filed May 31, 2022 (S.D. Fla.), alleging First, Fourth, Fourteenth Amendment violations and state-law battery and negligence.

Specifically, he dismissed without prejudice with leave to amend the plaintiff’s Fourteenth Amendment claims, her Fourth Amendment claims, and, with respect to the city only, her First Amendment claim. Judge Ruiz also ordered the defendant to file a Second Amended Complaint in compliance with his order on or before June 23, 2023.

After receiving an extension of time, the plaintiff filed a Second Amended Complaint on July 6, 2023. Among other things, the amended complaint pursued a bifurcated approach wherein the plaintiff alleged separate causes of action against the city and the other defendants, where applicable, and separated First Amendment claims into two claims–one for unlawful restriction on speech and the other for retaliation. The complaint also provided a name for one of the three John Doe officers and included as an additional defendant the city’s police chief.

The plaintiff filed a Third Amended Complaint on September 13, 2023, in which she made relatively modest changes to certain of her claims and removed references to one of the named FLPD defendants added in the Second Amended Complaint, substituting back John Doe 1.

The defendants sought summary judgment in a pair of filings made on December 5, 2023, and January 12, 2024. The plaintiff also filed a motion for partial summary judgment on January 12, 2024.

On September 4, 2024, Judge Ruiz issued an order granting in part and denying in part the various summary judgment motions. 2024 WL 4039849. Specifically, he granted summary judgment in favor of the individual defendants on all counts, citing both qualified and statutory immunity. With respect to the city, he denied summary judgment on the two First Amendment claims under the plaintiff’s failure-to-train Monell theory and denied summary judgment as to the state-law battery claim, holding that it would be up to a jury to determine whether the city was liable for the plaintiff’s injuries “through its policies, procedures, and officers’ conduct.”

On October 28, 2024, before the case proceeded to trial, the parties attended mediation and came to a full and final settlement of all claims, pending final consideration and approval by the Fort Lauderdale City Commission. The city commission approved [https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/broward/article296526834.html] a $1.975 million settlement at its meeting on December 3, 2024. As part of the settlement, FLPD also agreed to overhaul its internal policies. The court approved the settlement on December 23, 2024.

target:
In the aftermath of George Floyd's death in May 2020, nationwide protests erupted, including a significant demonstration in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on May 31, 2020. During the protest, the Fort Lauderdale Police Department (FLPD) attempted to disperse the crowd through use of tear gas and kinetic impact projectiles, otherwise known as rubber bullets.

The plaintiff in this case, a participant in the May 2020 demonstration, alleged she was shot in the eye by a direct impound round, causing severe, painful, and permanent physical and emotional injuries. In response to her injuries, she filed a lawsuit against the City of Fort Lauderdale and several FLPD officers in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida on May 31, 2022. The eight-count complaint alleged violations of her constitutional rights under the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments, as well as state law claims for battery and negligence. The plaintiff asserted municipal liability under a Monell “failure to train” theory. The plaintiff sought damages, including punitive damages, prejudgment interest on liquidated damages, costs, and compensatory damages. The matter was assigned to District Judge Rodolfo Armando Ruiz II.

The plaintiff filed an amended complaint on October 27, 2022, wherein she revised the list of named FLDP defendants and added two additional counts: a claim against the City of Fort Lauderdale for negligent instruction, training, and supervision of its officers and a Fourteenth Amendment Procedural Due Process claim against all defendants, alleging that FLDP officers did not issue a proper dispersal order prior to deploying force. For these additional claims, the plaintiff sought compensatory damages, costs, and injunctive relief.

On November 2 and November 10, 2022, the defendants filed a pair of motions to dismiss. Judge Ruiz issued an order on June 1, 2023, granting in part the various motions. 2023 WL 3750581. Specifically, he dismissed without prejudice with leave to amend the plaintiff’s Fourteenth Amendment claims, her Fourth Amendment claims, and, with respect to the city only, her First Amendment claim. Judge Ruiz also ordered the defendant to file a Second Amended Complaint in compliance with his order on or before June 23, 2023.

After receiving an extension of time, the plaintiff filed a Second Amended Complaint on July 6, 2023. Among other things, the amended complaint pursued a bifurcated approach wherein the plaintiff alleged separate causes of action against the city and the other defendants, where applicable, and separated First Amendment claims into two claims–one for unlawful restriction on speech and the other for retaliation. The complaint also provided a name for one of the three John Doe officers and included as an additional defendant the city’s police chief.

The plaintiff filed a Third Amended Complaint on September 13, 2023, in which she made relatively modest changes to certain of her claims and removed references to one of the named FLPD defendants added in the Second Amended Complaint, substituting back John Doe 1.

The defendants sought summary judgment in a pair of filings made on December 5, 2023, and January 12, 2024. The plaintiff also filed a motion for partial summary judgment on January 12, 2024.

On September 4, 2024, Judge Ruiz issued an order granting in part and denying in part the various summary judgment motions. 2024 WL 4039849. Specifically, he granted summary judgment in favor of the individual defendants on all counts, citing both qualified and statutory immunity. With respect to the city, he denied summary judgment on the two First Amendment claims under the plaintiff’s failure-to-train Monell theory and denied summary judgment as to the state-law battery claim, holding that it would be up to a jury to determine whether the city was liable for the plaintiff’s injuries “through its policies, procedures, and officers’ conduct.”

On October 28, 2024, before the case proceeded to trial, the parties attended mediation and came to a full and final settlement of all claims, pending final consideration and approval by the Fort Lauderdale City Commission. The city commission approved [https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/broward/article296526834.html] a $1.975 million settlement at its meeting on December 3, 2024. As part of the settlement, FLPD also agreed to overhaul its internal policies. The court approved the settlement on December 23, 2024.

With respect to the city, he denied summary judgment on the two First Amendment claims under the plaintiff’s failure-to-train Monell theory and denied summary judgment as to the state-law battery claim, holding that it would be up to a jury to determine whether the city was liable for the plaintiff’s injuries “through its policies, procedures, and officers’ conduct.”

annotation.explanation: September 4, 2024: Order granting in part and denying in part the various summary judgment motions; granting summary judgment to the individual defendants on all counts; denying summary judgment to the city on the two First Amendment Monell failure-to-train claims and the state-law battery claim.

The court found individual officers immune, but left for a jury the plaintiff’s Monell-based First Amendment claims and state-law battery claim against the City, focusing on potential liability through the City’s policies, procedures, and officers’ conduct.

All individual defendants were removed from the case on summary judgment, leaving no individual claims for trial.

During the protest, the Fort Lauderdale Police Department (FLPD) attempted to disperse the crowd through use of tear gas and kinetic impact projectiles, otherwise known as rubber bullets.

The plaintiff in this case, a participant in the May 2020 demonstration, alleged she was shot in the eye by a direct impound round, causing severe, painful, and permanent physical and emotional injuries. Judge Ruiz also ordered the defendant to file a Second Amended Complaint in compliance with his order on or before June 23, 2023.
